title: 'Good luck to them': McLaren boss on the latest luxe start-up cars
text:
The styling, which a spokesperson told LUXURY is “deliberately provocative”, is inspired by the famous H6C Dubonnet Xenia model of 1938, with its low, silver bodywork and sweeping tail. Just 19 of the new model will be built.

Martin Lischka, senior product manager at Automobili Pininfarina, says his company’s new electric Battista model will go on sale next year at €2 million, limited to 150 examples. It has a claimed 1400kW, almost 30 per cent more power than the 16-cylinder Bugatti Chiron.

“As well as this beautiful car, there will be a complete vehicle family,” says Lischka. Does that include a slightly more mainstream SUV, as rumoured?

Pininfarina’s new electric Battista model.

“I wouldn’t call it an SUV,” says Lishcka. "It’s more radical, more crossover, but still with a pure design, very sporty, very futuristic in terms of design. Definitely, we are not going to hit the mass market. Exclusivity, rarity are the key attributes we are seeing in the brand.”

Lagonda isn’t aiming for the mainstream, either, but hopes to sell thousands of cars, rather than tens or hundreds. Aston Martin has owned the brand since 1947 and plans to pitch it against Rolls-Royce and Bentley, with an SUV, then sedan, on offer from 2022. It presented the All-Terrain Concept at this year’s Geneva Motor Show.

Chief executive Andy Palmer says the company could have used its better-known Aston Martin brand for its electric cars, but that would make branding more difficult. “One of the things that make Tesla very compelling is that as a brand you understand it. Tesla is electric.”

The Lagonda All-Terrain Concept was unveiled at the Geneva Motor Show in March.

Palmer says the Lagonda brand is 120 years old and has a fairly high recognition in Britain, but doesn’t have much cut-through elsewhere. “But go back 20 years and look at Rolls-Royce and Bentley. VW managed to build Bentley into a mega-brand from something that was the hidden sister of Rolls-Royce, so it’s not impossible.

“I’m not underestimating the brand building, but it would be harder with a mixed message. The easiest way to communicate it is: Lagonda is 100 per cent electric.”

Advertisement

Palmer says battery power gives a lower noise level and doesn’t require the three-box “horse, carriage and trunk” of a petrol car, so the packaging can give back to the occupants the space that would be taken up by the internal combustion engine. The All-Terrain Concept is just over five metres long, but is claimed to have stretch-limo interior space.

LUXURY asked a few established manufacturers if the new breed is likely to succeed – and take market share from them.

“There are some really fresh ideas,” says Maurizio Reggiani, the chief technical officer of Lamborghini, though he said making an electric car isn’t quite as easy as some now think. “What they need to face is, really, what will be the rules of the game. If you see how homologation [the legal approval process] impacts the design of the car, the construction of the car, the engineering of the car, it is unbelievable.

I don’t believe for one minute those cars are going to drive and handle like a McLaren. They will be capable EVs in a supercar shell. — Mike Flewitt, McLaren CEO

“With electrification, one of the problems will be crash development. And there is a big job in terms of cooling. When you move from the concept car to the real car [then] we will see what will be the evolution of the revolution.”

In this regard, Lagonda has the advantage of Aston Martin backing, while Pininfarina is using an electrical system from Rimic of Croatia (Rimic impressed Porsche so much the German car maker bought a 10 per cent share). Pininfarina has proven production facilities where low volume specialty models have been made on behalf of Ferrari, Volvo and others.

McLaren CEO Mike Flewitt said of his new competitors: “Good luck to them; building cars is not an easy thing. But I don’t believe for one minute those cars are going to drive and handle like a McLaren. I believe they will be capable EVs in a supercar body shell.”

The interior of the spacious Lagonda All-Terrain Concept.

When Torsten Müller-Ötvös, CEO of Rolls-Royce, is asked if he feels any threats on the luxury or exclusivity side, he says: “Not at all.

“You are talking in this segment of really high-net-worth individuals, and for them the question is not, ‘Can I afford this?' If they like both, they go for both.

“They have garages like we have wardrobes. They will find for the occasion the right outfit, and if they like the Hispano-Suiza they will go for it.”

When asked about Lagonda – which believes 3000 a year should be possible, seeing as Rolls-Royce sold 4100 units in 2018 – Müller-Ötvös shrugs. “These are just announcements," he says. "We are here.”
description: Car companies new and old are hoping to cash in on the growing demand for ultra-fast, ultra-exclusive electric machines, but not everyone is convinced.
